advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> STUPID PICTURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>The same women has changed its shirt... But hey, what's the message behind this pictures ? Would it be that it's sexy to work on an Alpha Plus, or that women prefer men owning an Alpha Plus ?!</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> MBC-550 FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>''The personal computer 550, an opened door upon you computing future''</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH PICTURE (APRIL 1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This picture was used for promoting Educatel, a French private computing school.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is an advert from the ILLEL store</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ENGLISH LEAFLET</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT JULY 1982</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD (MAR. 86)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said<br><br><font color="#666666"> The electric typewriter's days are numbered. Because now there's a machine that put real wordprocessing power within everyone's reach.<br> The Amstrad PCW 8256 is a complete word-processor and a powerful computer in one unit.<br> And it's unbelievably low price includes a screen with built-in disc drive, keyboard, printer and word processing software...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE #4</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE EXTRACT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Rui Santos for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT #2 (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Compare the built-in features of leading microcomputers with the Atari personal computers. And go ahead, compare apples and oranges. Their most expensive against our least expensive: the Atari 400...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LEAFLET (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote>This man seems not to be so happy being more productive...<br> Note he uses a paper tape puncher to save newspaper articles. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (DEC. 1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to David Wilson for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMPUTERS IN THE EXAM ROOM</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, AUGUST 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href=§http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage§>Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">You may not have thought of all the reasons for buying a personal computer. There are exciting games, of course, but what about financial management, household records, even income tax? You need a versatile, sophisticated machine that's as limitless as your imagination. You need the Compucolor ll...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ITALIAN AD #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Special offer including italian books<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>http://angelmemories.cjb.net/</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JUNE 1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote>In 1986, the Alphatronic PC was bargained in many broker shops for a low price.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, SEPTEMBER 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The new revolutionnary modular system" <br><br> So you say... <br><br> "ITT 3030, the absolute intelligence" <br><br> Not less ! </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 8086 VERSION</strong></font><br><blockquote>In september 1982, Seattle Computer provided the 8086 version of the Gazelle with a free set of software: Microsoft MS-DOS, GW-Basic and the Perfect Writer word processor. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> POPULAR ELECTRONICS</strong></font><br><blockquote>Cover and extracts of a 6 page article in the January 1975 issue of Popular Electronics</blockquote>

computer.description:
This computer was designed as a versatile machine (!), it was supplied with five disks :
- Disk #1 (OS and language) : Operating System, 12 K Extended Basic, Line Editor. - Disk #2 (Games) : Star Trek, Black Jack and Star Wars. - Disk #3 (Home Accounting) : Budgeting, Checkbook Balancing - Disk #4 (Small Business Accounting) : Payroll, Inventory, Taxes, Invoicing, Check Printing - Disk #5 : Blank floppy disk
computer.name: VERSATILE 2
computer.ram: 16 KB (static RAM), extensible with 8K memory boards
